characters: AND WHAT IS IT WITH JEWISH MEN AND THEIR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Abrupt CLOSE UP on MAX, a plain wall behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He is 20, normal looking, not too nebbish, punkish, booki or stylish. He is a high-strung guy, enjoying a rare mome of un-self-consciousness.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's an old joke. It comes from "The Iliad," but I think it was popularized by Oscar Wilde. It goes like this: ...A bear's taking a shit, like, out in the woods one day. And he sees this rabbit, also taking a shit. The rabbit, wait, I mean, the bear, he's shitting up a storm, cuz he's been eating Mexican. The wiping's taking forever, and his shit keeps sticking to his fur. Wait, what happens next? Oh, right-- he asks the rabbit if he ever has trouble wiping. The rabbit says no, shit just slides right off him. So the bear picks the rabbit up and wipes his ass with him. (pause, as if for applause) Well, I never said it was a good joke. And see, that makes it perfect, because it's pretty much the story of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can now see that he's perched on a stool, wearing a RE shirt and old jeans. He gesticulates vaguely as he talks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Growing up, my parents were huge Woody Allen fans. Still are. Personally, I hate him. Same thing with the Beatles, such a part of my background that I must have been about 16 by the time I realized how useless it was to rebel by ignoring the Beatles or any other cultural artifact of their generation. Even if I did spend my childhood hearing my father go on and on about how, like, Nirvana would never mean anything because they're not the Beatles, blah-blah. I don't know, this is all starting to sound a little bit too angsty, you know, and that's about the last thing I'm going for here... Shit, I really got off track there, didn't I?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As Max shakes his head, a hanging RADIO MIKE comes into v It has the call letters of a college radio station on it. 2.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: High on the wall behind him, a glowing "ON AIR" light is revealed. The perspective is skewed, the studio appears cavernous and completely barren.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: YOUNG MAX, about five, sits on the floor and watches BANA with his FATHER, a large, relaxed man with a mustache who reclines in a tacky 80's chair and smokes a cigar.

dialogues.speaker: MAX, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Anyway, like the Beatles thingВ­ and this is the point of that whole long-winded exampleВ­ I was force-fed Woody Allen from a young age. I remember watching Bananas when I was about five. Of course, I hated it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Max is laughing hysterically at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max stands to the side, watching his younger self and his father. The radio mike hangs in front of him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my old house. We lived here, in a dull suburb of New York, until I was ten, when we moved to a different house in a different dull suburb of New York.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On TV, a woman is bit in the breast by a snake and is cha by a group of soldiers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daddy, why are they running after her?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someday, you'll understand. Pay attention, you'll learn something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young Max turns back to the screen, wide-eyed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In pajamas, ADOLESCENT MAX, 16, watches a newer TV in an identical family room. This time, ANNIE HALL is playing.

dialogues.speaker: MAX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh yeah. This wasn't the first time I saw Annie Hall, but it was the first time I actually appreciated it. I was flipping channels on a Saturday afternoon, and there it was, and I was stunned to find I loved it, more stunned to find that my parents may have had a point all along.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAX (V.O.) (cont'd) Although, they were definitely wrong about Bananas.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE ON: Adolescent Max, totally engrossed in the film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adolescent Max walks alone to class. Other students rush in groups. He looks a little lost.

dialogues.speaker: MAX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Oh God, high school. I hated this place. I was a Junior when I gave up trying to fit in. Fortunately, being a social outcast is a lot easier when your school is filled with idiots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pair of GOTH POSERS pass. Max keeps his distance. From other direction, a 6 FOOT TALL GIRL makes eyes at Max. He walks into a water fountain, drops his books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Adolescent Max gets hit in the face with a volleyball. Everyone laughs at him, including the COACH.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max stands to the side and winces.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There was something in Annie Hall I identified with. Maybe it was the style of humor, or the defeatist attitude, I don't know. All I know is, I kept going back. Different people are inspired by different things, and my source of inspiration became a 20-year-old movie about a failed relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The volleyball rolls over and he picks it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From behind Max, we see the station as it really is: smal dark, cramped, and totally filled with crap. Max wears headphones, sits before a large console and audio gear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He now holds a volleyball.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So after high school I ended up here. There was never really any choice, not going to college was not an option. Of course, I brought Annie with me. Good thing, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watching it quickly became about the only thing I could count on to go right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max is with five friends in the double, and they all have lingering style-baggage from high school (eg. bad haircut

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was freshmen year when we started watching Annie Hall as a tradition.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeez, this must have been the very first time. What's Amy doing here? I'm pretty sure Amy wasn't here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: AMY is attractive, bookish, and sitting on Max's bed. CHARLES, a skinny guy in a large chair, tries to get her attention by wiggling his eyebrows seductively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max puts the tape in the VCR, hits rewind, and moves to s on his bed. He pauses when he sees how close he'll come t Amy. Finally, he climbs over her and awkwardly sits at th far end.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amy watches, rolls her eyes, and looks at BETH, who shake her head sadly. Beth is pretty in an earthy way, spunky a sad at the same time. She looks sympathetically at Max, w is trying not to act nervous (and failing).

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The couple is SAM, who's short and charismatic, with a co slightly punkish personal style; and JEN, same height, cu and serious, conservative dress. They lie on the floor together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's Sam and Jen. Sam was the alpha- male of our group, which tends to consist mostly of zeta-males. He had been going out with Jen a couple weeks and we were all waiting to see if she would change him...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam slides a pillow under her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you comfortable, honey?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fine, Sam. I was worried about you. Sure you don't want me to move over? 5.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh no, no, Jen, if you're happy, I'm happy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max and Charles exchange a look-- there they go again. Ma makes a show of putting a pillow under a large Darth Vade doll. Beth laughs, Amy is amused. Sam looks back and is embarrassed. Jen rolls her eyes and gives Sam a look.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are we gonna watch this movie or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Annie Hall's credits roll. Sam snaps on the lights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, what a good movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, that was so sad! Relationships don't have to be like that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see why you like this so much. It reminded me of you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, thanks, I guess. Does that mean you liked it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max and Amy stand and face each other as the lights fade black around everyone else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't say I liked it, I said it reminded me of you. It reminded me of what I didn't like about you, the cynicism, the neurotic insecurity, and oh yeah, when you started calling me every day. All the reasons we were never more than friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, at least you're being honest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course I'm being honest. This is a fantasy extrapolated from a flashback. How could I lie to you? 6.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm the only person I know who gets insulted in his own fantasies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles walks by, Amy takes his arm, and they disappear i the surrounding darkness, which DISSOLVES TO:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and again Max is alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, Amy set the tone for the rest of college...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The movie is Annie Hall. The theater is emptying. Suddenl ERICA bursts through the crowd. Erica is mad. Max follows behind her, placating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max freezes in place. The entire crowd of students turns look at him. He manages a weak smile and turns back to Er but she's gone, out the doors into the night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max turns back to the crowd and shrugs, but the crowd tur away. Max suddenly sees someone: Beth, looking at him. He blushes, self-conscious, and hurries away.

dialogues.speaker: MAX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: And even when it went right, it didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max and STACY stumble in, inebriated, laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And then I, then I, after I called the pizza place, I called an ambulance, and timed them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who won?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pizza, of course. The paramedics took 35 minutes to arrive. 7.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you! Did you get in trouble?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Station Manager said I couldn't go on the air ever again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what'd you do?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gave him the pizza!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They collapse on the bed, laughing. Stacy rolls over and kisses Max on the lips. His eyes go wide and he frantical crawls backwards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Don't you like me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It would never work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How would you know?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. I have a sixth sense.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You see dead people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I see dead relationships.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stacy sits up, frustrated, the mood ruined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was all true, but there was something else, though. I mean, there I was, drunk, in a girl's bedroom, and the only thought running through my mind was...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max speaks to someone O.S.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ..."What about Beth?"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max is talking to Beth. It's a beautiful Spring day. 8.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, I know we're just friends, but you really mean a lot to me and we've been spending a lot of time together lately, and maybe... I guess what I'm saying is, maybe we could try going out on a date or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I mean, it wouldn't have to be, uh...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We wouldn't have to... What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd love to. How's tomorrow night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, yeah, it would have to be after, or maybe... Yeah, tomorrow, uh, tomorrow night's fine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. I know the perfect thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She splits, leaving Max befuddled at his change of fortun

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max and Beth are walking through the night in overcoats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not until Sam and Jen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A perfect record. Wow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't get what the fuss is. I knew you and that Chris guy wouldn't last a week as soon as I saw you together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you can tell with everybody? I don't know if that's sad or incredible. 9.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or incredibly sad. I'm amazed I'm the only one who can tell. Take any couple. If it's not incompatible lifestyles, it's conflicting priorities. If it's not that, it's usually clashing levels of self- esteem. It's always something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Living with you would be a nightmare. I'd be afraid to bring any boyfriends home. Oh, uh, sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, just because I see it, doesn't mean I talk about it. I don't say a word to my suitemates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You guys never talk about anything important anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, come on, we have philosophical discussions all the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like whether Voltron could kill the Transformers?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To name one hot-button issue, yes. You want us to talk about girls? Sam is nearly married to Jen, Charles doesn't want his relationships to last, Tommy's girlfriends are located in online chatrooms across the country, and Scott, well... you know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For such "close" friends, it just seems weird, that's all. I must admit, I'm a lot closer to you than any of them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are at the Library.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are doing here? 10.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max and Beth remove their coats, revealing formal wear. O STUDENTS give them looks. An older female LIBRARIAN approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, you must have the reservation for booth seven.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, that's us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right this way, then.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Reservation"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'd be surprised how many of you lovebirds we get in here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She winks and leads them to the elevator. Beth smiles shy and looks at Max, but he is merely embarrassed. Her smile fades.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max and Beth are watching the opening credits of Annie Ha on a tiny TV in a cubicle. They are surrounded by other students in cubicles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't this great?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, this isn't exactly what I had in mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For starters, I have a serious problem with spending any time in the library when I don't have to. I'm here once or twice a year as it is. Plus... (holds up headphones) What's the point of seeing this together if we're wearing headphones?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not be with a life-sized cardboard cut-out? That way you can be with someone famous, even a dead person. Wouldn't you rather be with Elvis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shhh...!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or Batman?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't you just enjoy the moment?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm a little nervous. It's like, our first date and everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh. Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max and Beth leave the library. Their dispositions have switched: Max is perky while Beth is subdued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe how many great lines there are. Even the little throwaways, like when she parks and he's like, "That's okay, we can walk to the curb from here."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I loved it, I'm serious. I'm so glad we did this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, me too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But man, relationships are a lot of work, aren't they?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, sure, sometimes...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth stops him, and they sit on a bench. The night is col They sit close and lean in, speaking in hushed tones. 12.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If I'm going to jump into anything with you, Max, I need some sign that you're serious about it. About me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You want me to get a tattoo or something?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you've gotta admit, you're the most pessimistic person in the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously you've never met my mother.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can you be serious for a second?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess you really haven't met my mother...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth isn't laughing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, Max, this isn't going to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a second.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay. No more jokes. Now. Tell me how you feel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: About me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you doing this? Since when have you gotten "serious" about relationships? Your last boyfriend dumped you after four days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth sits up, pulls her jacket closed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that was intimate. Thanks, Max. 13.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No wait, I'm sorry, I'm sorry, hold on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, I don't think this is such a good idea. I mean, it would be really foolish to jeopardize our friendship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it wouldn't!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We shouldn't have rushed into this. I'm sure you know it wouldn't have worked out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Please tell me we haven't hurt our friendship. You don't even know how much you mean to me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm starting to get the idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's dazed, slightly ill. Beth touches his arm gently and walks away. Max turns to us. A radio mike swings into vie

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things weren't the same after. We quickly became the kind of friends who say Hi on the paths but don't stop walking. Then, she moved across campus and changed majors, and basically, except for the random phone call, I haven't seen her in ages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAX, thoughtful. PULL BACK TO REVEAL:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, speaking in the empty station, suddenly gets intense

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All these dates had one thing in common! And it took Charles, of all people, to point it out to me. 14.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's late January and the campus is showing signs of a temperamental winter.

dialogues.speaker: MAX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: This morning, we were skipping class.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max and Charles walk across the quad towards us. At first they are only specks in the distance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, you're insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's ridiculous that even at a liberal school like this, I have to put up with anti-Semitism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you got a C minus! Don't you think you're getting carried away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He couldn't just fail me, think about it. The paper was about my grandparents' experience in the Holocaust.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your paranoia has always been out of control, but this is absurd.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't understand, you're not Jewish.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Neither are you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the professor probably thinks I am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And wasn't that the paper that you handed in two weeks late?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what else? I think he might be German.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Professor Wang? Will you stop it...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can now see that Charles has a fedora cocked back on h head, and is wearing incongruous "Vegas" clothes. 15.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They walk past and into the University Center.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a low-traffic time of day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do you want to do tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not sure. It is the beginning of the semester, it's time for our Annie Hall night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have you ever noticed that the more Annie Hall you watch, the less successful you are romantically? I think we'd do much better if we watched, say, Ocean's 11.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about? If you're sick of Annie Hall, that's one thing, but don't blame our sad little lives on it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles picks out breath mints.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm telling you, I was thinking about this over break. Ever since we started watching it, what has your love life been like? And mine? Every semester, we watch this movie, and then spend the semester alone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone? Last semester you hooked up with like a dozen women.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know actresses don't count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm looking for a meaningful, sophisticated relationship. Like Frank and Ava. No more shallow dames for this cat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where did you get this grudge against my favorite film? 16.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm just kidding around, Max. We'll watch it tomorrow. Tonight, there's a party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And anyway, your theory fails to account for our collective dorkiness and bad haircuts. Plus, look at Sam.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam hasn't seen Annie Hall since freshman year, and he's in his third year with Jen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So look at what not watching can do to you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch. Why are you still on this? I said I was kidding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a nightmare. I dunno why I can't stop thinking about these things. I guess I've been a little restless lately, since getting back from winter break. Everything's been kind of weird lately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He grabs a CD from a rack.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hope you enjoyed this week's Reggae Revelry Hour. This is Max filling in for Rasta Ronnie, taking you out with a little Bad Religion.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He puts in the CD, hits "Shuffle/Repeat," and leaves. The caller request lines blink furiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE CARD: white on black: "SUNDAY"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max's dormitory suite: four bedrooms off a common room, w has three battered couches, a coffee table, and in a corn several small fridges and two televisions in a pile.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Christmas lights are still up. A neon `Guinness' sign dwa it all. 17.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max and Charles are here, standing, while Sam and Jen sit one couch and SCOTT and AMANDA sit on the other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles puts on his gloves and coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, you're coming and that's the end of it. When's the last time you went to a party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares? It's unnatural. If I went into a stranger's house and ate their food under any other circumstance, I'd be arrested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not taking no. With Sam on board, it's gonna be like old times.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He gestures at Sam, who stands. Unlike the hipster from freshman year, Sam now resembles a middle-aged accountant There are bags under his eyes and square clothes on his b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I haven't been out with you guys in ages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jen looks up from her magazine with disapproval.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're going out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, honey, just for a little while.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know I have to work until midnight. It's not my fault the supervisor won't let me out of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She glares. He teeters between his friends and his girlfriend. His girlfriend wins. He sits back down, tryin hide his disappointment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She has a point, guys. I should catch up on my chemistry reading anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The guys roll their eyes, let down but unsurprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Across the room are SCOTT, perpetually poker-faced and reserved, and AMANDA, understated, with the subdued manne a long-suffering wallflower. 18.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits off to the side, sneaking looks at Scott. He's watching a golf-related infomercial.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So Scott... How come you're not going out with Charles and Max?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can't go. Graphic design work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh really? I have work, too, but it's okay, I got a lot done today. What do you have to do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Graphic design work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TOMMY enters. He's preppier than anyone else, conservativ clothes capped off by a goofy smile and thick glasses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's up, all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy, at last. Save me from this lounge lizard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, what are you doing tonight?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Physics lab. Fortunately, the semester's just begun, so before the work piles up, I can party. That's why the beginning of the semester rules.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great, so come party with me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't, I have physics work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He disappears into his room. Charles takes Max's hat from hook, jams it on his head, and shoves him towards the doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A typically lame college party, still early in the night. furniture is "student budget modern" type. A jazz record plays quietly, while pretentiously-dressed PARTY-GOERS si wine and eat cheese and crackers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max and Charles survey the room, drinks in hand. 19.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cheers to a new semester, full of potential that will surely go to waste.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They toast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is it, I'm telling you. This is the semester I pass all my classes and meet the dame of my dreams.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good luck, and may she have a sister.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More importantly, may she grant us our occasional freedom.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, forget about Sam. I don't like it any more than you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's become a total non-entity. Freshman year, we were like Frank and Deano. Now it's like Frank and freakin' Peter Lawford.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, he was one of my best friends. Now we share a room and he's like a stranger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hottie at 3 o'clock. Keep an eye on her for me so it doesn't look like I'm interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, right, then if you fail to sodomize her, you'll blame me. Me, or Annie Hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, all I said was, it would explain our lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The problem is, every crazy theory explains something. I took a class last semester with a professor who claimed that the planet is being destroyed by white, male, meat-eating capitalists.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? Everybody knows that. 20.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But she had a theory that explained how: apparently racism, sexism, socialism, environmentalism, and vegetarianism are all inherently linked. I brought a Big Mac to the first class, and I thought I was going to be the victim of a vegan- socialist uprising.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam walks in and makes a beeline for the guys. Excitement

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey! I made it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, the laws of nature have stopped working. Maybe I should try to meet some chicks after all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How'd you get away?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told her I was going to the lab. She doesn't mind if I'm working while she is. How's the party?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sucks. Who are they trying to be, with this wine and cheese? What kind of party doesn't even have beer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can get into this. It's better than those frat parties. Check out the fox in the beret.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, it's so good to be out. Between Jen, homework, and labs, I hardly have time for anything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You could always change your major. You'd have a lot more free time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel the same way about science that I do about Jen. It's a lot of work, but it's worth it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have doubts about both, actually. But still, what could be dumber than changing your major for a girl?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Changing your girl for a major.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you do it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It wouldn't be an issue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course not, when has studying ever interfered with what's important, like video hockey or your radio show that nobody listens to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I meant, I'd have to have a girl first. And lay off the radio show. There's a reason I took the 3am slot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And every time I see you doing homework, you're taking a break. You're the best I've ever seen when it comes to procrastinating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should be, procrastination is one of my favorite hobbies. Isn't it funny that my two favorite hobbies rhyme?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles' expression turns sour as he looks across the roo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, shit, Sara's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: SARA, good-looking and excitable, arrives with a theatric flourish. Her age and manner indicate, among other things that she is a freshman.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ta-daaa! Hey guys, what's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were just talking about the mediocre resonations of sub-hybrid fields.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you think they're mediocre. Those guys rock. 22.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (doesn't get it, doesn't care) Oh. Well, I just wanted to stop by and say "hey" to my favorite guys. So hey! How was everyone's break?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She is clearly talking to Charles, who is scanning the ro over her shoulder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could have been better but it could have been worse. For me, that's good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mine was great! I partied with my best friend Melanie, who I haven't seen in ages. Aren't these parties just the best? So much better than the theater group parties.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno, it's a bunch of 21-year-olds who want the 18-year-olds to know how mature they are.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Charles, you going to the fraternity party after this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gonna be back at your suite then? Maybe I'll stop by.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah, we should be back in, uh, many many hours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay then, I'll catch up with you guys later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She tugs on Charles's shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I missed you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves. 23.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, I was hoping to avoid her for at least a few more days.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you have against her? She seems nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First, she makes my skin crawl. Second, if word gets out, it'll ruin my reputation in the freshman dorms.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam looks to Max for the real story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never hook up with people in your cast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am a world-class knucklehead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A pretty girl approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry to interrupt, I thought I heard one of you say "Max."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of us is Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, great, just as I hoped. I just wanted to say, I heard your radio show last week and I thought it was great. Thoughtful and poignant and funny, too. You know, you look just like I imagined, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God, you heard my show?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're Max? Then who are you? 24.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles. I'm an actor.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You okay? You look like you're in pain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't get it, I can't do my show if I even suspect someone is listening. Now I have to change time slots. Again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry, I didn't realize I wasn't supposed to listen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it's no good, the whole episode is ruined. This is a disaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I work in theater a lot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, listen. I was kidding. Your show actually kind of sucked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just kidding! It was awesome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I also direct.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, when did you tune in? I need to know which episode you ruined.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: At one point you dialed a phone sex line. It was hilarious. It's not every day someone calls 1-900-4RIMJOBS to discuss politics.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam quickly pulls Charles away as he starts to comment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And she hung up. "This isn't the place for that kind of talk..." 25.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's like, for four dollars a minute, you should talk about whatever you want. You know the country's in trouble when a phone sex operator thinks talking politics is beneath her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Perhaps she'd been screwed by politicians. Phone sex is just pretend but politics... I know my ass is still sore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He catches himself and falters. Julie notices something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I'm being flagged down by my over- protective friends. It was nice meeting you, though.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, wait. How did you know about my show?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Someone mentioned you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anybody I know? Oh, duh, I guess it would have to be someone I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was from a good source. I was told I'd like you, but to really know you, I should hear your show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She appraises him for a beat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was Beth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And with that, she leaves. Max watches her, loses her in crowd. Something catches his eye across the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: MAX'S POV: Sam is in a corner, trapped by an upset Jen. F his gestures, he is on the defensive.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles moseys over. 26.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Check it. Jen traded shifts and got out of work, so she went to the lab to surprise Sam. He wasn't there, and then Tommy gave away that he was here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Busted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how. Let's bail before the beheadings begin. Plus, The Rat Pack's on HBO later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They put on their coats.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you stand that show?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, it's research. It's why I got three phone numbers, Max, while you were talking to that cutie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Cutie"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's right. You get her name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We just met. I was working up to it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Man, you're worse at picking up chicks than me. We are one sad couple of bozos.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max looks at him like he's insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alone, he kicks snow off his boots as he sheds his winter layers. He taps the answering machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, hi, Max. Guess who? It's Beth. Been a while, huh? Since that lunch last August that somehow never happened. Anyway, uh, just checking in, I guess. Hope your break was okay. Uh, and---- 27.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BEEEEEEEP. The machine cuts her off. Max sighs, picks up phone, dials.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello? Beth?... Sorry... Hello...? Hey, how's it going?... Yeah, in person... Too long... So anyway, I just wanted to say hi, and also, stop telling people to listen to my show... Of course I'm serious... Stop laughing... Of course I haven't changed...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE CARD: white on black: "MONDAY"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sara sleeps on a couch. Charles, wearing only boxers, hun over and mostly asleep, passes through the living room. H stubs his toe and crashes into the wall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ow! Shit! Ow!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He continues into the bathroom. Sara wakes up and looks around groggily. A FLUSH. Charles walks out of the bathro and blinks at Sara with surprise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jeeezzus! Shit, sorry you um...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's all right, this isn't the first time this has happened. At least this time I'm not the naked one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that, I mean, I'm just surprised to see you here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm, yeah, I must have shown up after you came back, or something. I was planning to go home, but I guess I fell asleep.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She waits for something from Charles. He doesn't respond. reluctantly gets to her feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Anyway, I, uh, I've got a bunch of stuff to do. I'll see you later.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bye. 28.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: As she leaves, Max comes in, still in last night's clothe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You all right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She's around all the time! I chose to live with my hombres, not her. She's got to realize that we're not right for each other and get on with her life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean, I thought I heard you fall or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, what? I just stubbed my toe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That sucks. Bad way to start the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The toe's the least of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is funny, in a way. Yesterday you were complaining about not having any girls. Now you're complaining because you have one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. It's a shame. And I was attracted to her once, too. What happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Want me to tell you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No! I think I've heard enough from the Nostradamus of failed relationships to last a lifetime.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speaking of failed relationships, I was thinking about your Annie Hall theory. Specifically, I was thinking that you're insane.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I was joking, so why do you keep bringing it up? 29.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's like you insulted my religion. Like, "Hey, Cardinal, I think Jesus might be why you're not getting laid..."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your attitude's too dour. You've gotta be more fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not my fault Annie Hall's honest about the futility of romance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're just a wuss. The very thought of not seeing that movie scares you. You're like a junkie, you need movie methadone. Like, from now on you can only see Manhattan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Forget it, I hate Manhattan.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think addicts like Methadone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My Uncle Harry didn't seem to mind.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are we doing for lunch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott enters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You mean breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, I'm supposed to eat with Beth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't look excited at the prospect, but Charles does

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beth? Wow. She hasn't been around in ages. Say hi for me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max walks with Beth down the city street. She carries an umbrella and scans the skies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't it supposed to rain? 30.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, it's been ten minutes and we're still discussing the weather.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So? Think of all the people who've died in hurricanes. I bet they think it's a worthy issue.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just feel like there are other things we could be talking about. You're the one person I could rely on to say something original.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, what classes are you taking?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This was a mistake, wasn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They stop in front of Frannie's, a small greasy spoon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, let's just call it a day. I was excited to hear from you, but I can't take you like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A COUPLE exit, the guy holds the door for them. They hesitate. Suddenly, from inside:

dialogues.speaker: CHARLES, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Max! Beth! Come sit with us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm sorry. Don't worry about it. To be honest, it's nice being with someone besides my suitemates for a change.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They look in and see...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...Charles, Scott, Amanda, Sam and Jen, seated around a h table. They are waving them in. Beth enters, Max reluctan follows. 31.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my, God, Beth! It's great to see you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's been so long!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone scoots over to make room. Max is still stunned b has no choice. He sits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How did we ever fall out of touch? We shouldn't let that happen again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know! I even miss this place. I live on the wrong side of campus now. You guys still come here? It's so dark and the menu is tiny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It never changes, that's why.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you gonna get?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe an omelet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you have to get eggs? I'm allergic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So don't get the eggs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's just that, it's the smell. It's the smell that bothers me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you serious? How can you be allergic to the smell of my eggs?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry about it, Jen. He's just incredibly picky about food.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Even other people's.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, if you're going to have eggs, let me at least switch seats with Sam, so I'll be farther away from it. 32.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, what's up with you today? Join a support group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: If it really bothers you, why don't you and Beth switch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This would put Beth next to Charles. She looks at him and smiles. Unable to help herself, she smiles back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about people at other tables? Should we ask the management to stop serving egg- products to people upwind of you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why can't you just get along with everyone for once?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, alright, you win, we'll switch. Come on, Beth, get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What makes you so sure I'm gonna switch? I don't think I'm gonna move.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't give in, Beth. I've got your back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You owe me. Remember when you threw that egg at me in the dining hall?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, I'll get up. But I'm ordering an omelet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She sits down next to Charles and they smile at each othe

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max walks down the street toward an ATM, where a long lin college students has formed. Next to the ATM is an arthou theater. The marquee reads "Thru Valentine's Day: ANNIE H and CASABLANCA."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He joins the ATM line. A moment later, Julie walks by. Sh notices him and stops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi. Look at this line. 33.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, hey. Yeah, I hate coming here this time of day, but I need money. You know, gambling debts and all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't ATMs great? They save so much time. Think about what life must have been like before them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't support an acronym without knowing what it stands for. I once joined NAMBLA because I thought it was an animal rights group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She laughs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, are you a junior, too?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm listed as a sophomore, but I've taken some time off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What're you majoring in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why is that always the first question?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was my second question.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And how would you answer it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'd be honest. Oh, wait. Media Studies. This week, I'm majoring in Media Studies. I used to be a double-major, Renaissance Footwear and Neurosurgery, but, ya know, it was just too hard to get course credit for watching movies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet. Me, I'm in Soc., but I'm leaning toward Business, or Psych. Or Art History.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't you just be undeclared? 34.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not my style.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max's turn-- but he spots ANNIE HALL on the marquee. Impulsively, he turns Julie to face him, so that her back to it. In doing so, he steps away from the ATM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay? I thought you needed money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, I forgot, my bookie takes checks now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seriously, is everything okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Actually, yes. But I need something from you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your name.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Julie, no nickname. Don't even think of calling me "Jewel."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, Julie with no nickname, I, um, I'll see you around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Probably.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She leaves. Max goes back to the end of the line.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lounging are Max and Charles, Sam and Tommy, and Scott an Amanda.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles pulls a bottle of vodka from a newsbox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, which of you cats is in?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's only Monday. 35.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, it's only Monday? Now I really need a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles takes two mugs off the floor, throws their conten into a plant, and pours.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tommy is on one end of a couch, sneaking looks at Amanda, the middle, who is sneaking looks at Scott, on the other

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How was your day?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My day sucked. I spent six hours in the lab and four hours in class. And tonight, I have to study for two tests.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It better be worth it when I get into grad school.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott, how's the design project coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slowly. There are a couple problems.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott gets up and leaves the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, I have an extra ticket to this concert tomorrow night.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Charles, Sam, and Max look on with alarm: is he really go through with this, here, now? Amanda takes the bait.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Ani DiFranco show? Awesome! That's been sold out for weeks! 36.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not Ani DiFranco, it's better-- two, front row seats at the Campus Choir charity show.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So do ya wanna go?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno. Why don't you call me tomorrow during the day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's getting late. See you guys later.

dialogues.speaker: SAM
dialogues.text: Bye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See you tomorrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda exits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow, that went pretty good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Using Ani DiFranco to get laid. I've gotta try that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She'll never give up on Scott.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not like I expect anything, I just like to spend time with her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott wanders back in with a copy of Wired magazine. Tomm stands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott, do you mind if I take Amanda to a concert tomorrow night?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would I? 37.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think so, but not asking would be wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it wouldn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's not even a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's nothing serious, but it is a date.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But they're going as friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They are friends.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She probably won't even go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott sits and reads his magazine. Tommy drops heavily in chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whenever you're done, someone please give me an update on my sex life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How does "sex life" enter, if she might not be going, and if she does, it's just as friends?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait, can you be on a date with someone you're not dating?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes. No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't think it was such a big deal!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just wanted to make sure it didn't bother you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott looks at him like, Are you kidding? and goes back t his magazine. Tommy looks frustrated. 38.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This conversation is starting to bother me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE CARD: white on black: "TUESDAY"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max shakes a tumbler as Amanda keeps time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tired yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is ridiculous. What other art form involves industrial toxins and complex chemical reactions? Nobody ever got cancer from dancing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're so paranoid.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm serious. Chemicals make me very nervous. Isn't this how the Unabomber got started?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He continues shaking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, do I bother Scott when I'm around?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, boy, this fixer smells delicious...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: `Cuz, sometimes it seems like I do. I know he's not, like, interested, but then, sometimes it seems like he is. I just don't want it to be awkward. Please, tell me the truth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I, uh, I mean, the truth is, it's not a topic. It doesn't bother him, or us. Or I mean, he doesn't talk about it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So he never talks about me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I mean, no, not with us, anyway. 39.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I knew it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen. All I'm trying to say is, you're not a topic that comes up very often.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So with all the time we spend together, none of you have any opinion of me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda storms out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, that's not... what I meant. Oy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda returns, still upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's time! To unroll the film.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max, startled, fumbles open the tumbler.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, Amanda. Scott likes you as much as we all do, so it doesn't leave much room for discussion. We mostly only talk about what we hate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know. It's just sometimes, I wish...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amanda takes the negatives, opens the door to a closet, h them from a clothespin, and leaves. Max takes his, select clothespin, and knocks several others to the floor. He tr to pick them up, and manages to step on them.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Max? Are you coming?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He throws the crumpled negatives in the closet and grabs bag. At the door, he notices one stuck to his shoe.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes the negative off his shoe, almost knocking himse over, and hurries out. 40.

dialogues.speaker: AMANDA, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Why does it always take you so long in there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max enters to find Sam playing video hockey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, remember the scene in Swingers when they play this? That was awesome. I love movie scenes I can relate to.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He sits down next to him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Wasn't there also a video hockey scene in Mallrats?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, you're thinking of Chasing Amy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Which one had all the comic book stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They both did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the Star Wars stuff?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mallrats, Clerks, and Dogma.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about the last one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doesn't count, it was just an ad for all his other films.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta admit, it's fucking cheap for a movie to refer to other movies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? We do it real life. We're doing it right now. What you're saying is, if this was a movie, it wouldn't be any good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Our lives would make an awful movie. 41.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But if our lives were a movie, you'd never be able to say that. You'd be giving the critics the perfect quote to pan it with.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So fucking what? It's a shitty movie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam drops his controller and gets up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How come you only play this one video game?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Video hockey is my game. Like a swan, I mate for life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: More like the loon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max looks him over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy shit, you and Jen broke up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Your prediction finally came true. Come on, let's hit the bar. I need a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A crummy collegiate dive. Sam and Max drink coffees.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, so what happened?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were just hanging out, and she told me she loves me. Completely out of the blue. She says things like that sometimes, things like "I love that you're my boyfriend," ya know? But usually when we're in bed or something. But this time it was different, all we were doing was watching TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Porn? 42.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Almost. It was "our" show, the one we like to get romantic to...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam and Jen watch "The X-Files." Max stands, observing. J can't see him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was just tired of trying to tell her what she wanted to hear all the time, so I tried to be honest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been together a long time and I really care about you, but I don't know if I love you. This is tough to say, but I think something might be missing from our relationship.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Something's missing?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, not completely... I don't know if I can explain it. See...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There are three things I look for in a girl: heart, body, and mind. And well, you've got the body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max is stunned and laughs. Jen is stunned, too, and runs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus. You think you know someone pretty well and then they do something like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When she comes back, she slaps me in the face and makes me leave. Then she calls, crying, and asks me to come over. When I go back, she kicks me out and says she never wants to see me again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fifty bucks says there's a message on the machine when we get back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max sits, and the background DISSOLVES back TO: 43.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it really so bad? I couldn't lie to her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you know that no matter how often girls tell you they want honesty, they never really mean it? Nobody does!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, I fucked up, alright? I didn't know what to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's too bad it ended like this. I'm really sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Me too. It'll be hard to get used to, but at least we ended it early.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sam throws some money on the table and they get up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, you know what I'm in the mood for? Annie Hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus, that film...-- Have you heard Charles' theory?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, Max, I can only deal with one mid-life crisis at a time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't believe you said that to her. That's so cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, at least I can hang out with my friends again. 44.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "New wave dance party" in The Pub, the small, grungy club campus. A DJ plays something obscure from the 80s. Some people dance, while the rest, including Max, Charles, and Scott, sit at tables by the coffee bar in the back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I was talking to Amanda the other day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that Thursday? Because there was that half hour when she didn't call or visit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scott, why don't you go for her? You seem to get along well.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She follows me around now. If we slept together, I'd never get rid of her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're exaggerating.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at Sam and Jen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bad example: it could never get that bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ouch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then look at Charles and Sara.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, ouch for real this time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max looks O.S. and goes pale.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, she's here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie walks through the crowd in their direction, but sto at another table, talking to friends. Max exhales slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That dame from History class? 45.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. She's, she's just a girl. I shouldn't have mentioned it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you did mention it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ohhh, that's the one from the party.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Get her name yet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's "Julie"... Julie. She's cute, and she seems interesting, but I'm sure she has all kinds of horrible flaws I don't know about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh-oh. This is bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you mean?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're thinking about her. You're already making yourself nervous and you barely know her. You do this every time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I wonder if maybe I should go say hi.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, this is what I'm talking about. If you don't go hit on her, I will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you know the guys she's talking to?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. The guy in the jacket is annoying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie sees him. He freezes like a deer in headlights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, shit, shit, she's looking this way. Fuck. What should I...? 46.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You have no choice. If you back away now, she'll never get to see the rest of your annoying personality traits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right. I can't deprive her of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie is with ANDY and MARK. Andy is your basic hippie, resplendent in a ridiculous green shag jacket. Mark has a and is wearing a J Crew long-sleeve shirt over a Dave Matthews Band t-shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max! What's going on?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you guys know Max? This is Mark...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wassup.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ...And Andy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Max, how's it hanging, bud?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine. I, uh, really like your jacket. Is that real carpet?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, man. I couldn't believe my luck when I saw it. This shade of shag is, like, so rare. I was like, woah...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, are we gonna burn this or what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, man. Hey, you guys are like all invited, if you can handle some kind bud... "Maui wowey," you know? 47.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aloha?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark, Julie, and Max sit around a wooden table in a small apartment's kitchen. Andy puts on a CD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey man, you like Zappa?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dweezil or Moon Unit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Frank. (then gets it, laughs) Man, that isn't even funny. You should check out "Apostrophe" some time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Apostrophe"?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's an album.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought he was correcting my grammar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get anyone beers? Julie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark distributes beers to everyone but Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Max, we don't have enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah, sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You want mine? 48.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thanks. I'm kinda picky about beer. I'm more into stuff like Guinness, Bass, Killians.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's so... British.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a coincidence, I swear.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie has trouble opening her beer. Mark rushes over with keychain.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought Guinness was going to be cool, but it sucks. Made me nauseous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dude, puking blows. That's why I smoke weed. You get high right away and no hangover!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy pulls out a baggie of marijuana, and rummages throug the closet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, I don't know. Giving me pot is like letting Richard Simmons smoke crack. I'm paranoid enough as it is.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well, some people just can't handle their bud.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark glares disparagingly at him while Max pretends to examine the ceiling. Julie pulls out cigarettes, lights u

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy, what are you looking for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Andy finds it: a gigantic bong made from a vacuum cleaner sets it up on the counter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. I bet you could use that for yard work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie, you don't smoke either, right?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? 49.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. I used to, but when it became my social life I knew I needed to stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kind of like why I stopped playing Dungeons and Dragons. It was, uh, in sixth grade, but it was kind of similar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why don't we go smoke in the living room?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, Ampersand's crashing on the couch tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Ampersand"? What kind of name is that, Esperanto?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, his name was Mike, but he couldn't cope. He thought it was, like, too square. He wanted a name that would tell people, here is a person that only the brave will understand! Here is a person living beyond the walls!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He must have been listening to "Apostrophe" at the time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or Prince, cuz, like, Prince's name was a squiggly-thing. But Mike wanted something powerful, meaningful, and above all, something you could type. Therefore, "Ampersand." It's already on the keyboard and everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How much did that cost? Because I have a friend who wants to change his name to Not Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is his name Bill?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, Not Bill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What about originally? 50.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Originally he wanted to change it to something else.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark steps forward and pushes up a sleeve.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Julie, check out my new tattoo.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's got an anchor on his right biceps. Max snickers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, Mark, that's really cool.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know it's not what you suggested, but I needed something more... masculine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max quietly whistles "Popeye the Sailor Man."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You think you're pretty funny, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: C'mon, I thought hippies were mellow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You just call me a hippie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sorry, Popeye, I guess I was thrown by the Dave Matthews merchandise.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm in a frat, geek.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well shouldn't you be back there date- raping someone?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie, where did you find this creep?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max and Mark both look to Julie-- she must pick a side. She pulls on her cigarette, then turns to Mark.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark, lay off. Go take a hit off the Hoover and mellow out. (turning to Max) Max, I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, it's okay. I'm cool. 51.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He takes a beer from the table, fumbles, and drops it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, it's time. It's getting late anyway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She puts out her cigarette and grabs her coat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max and Julie approach Shelly Hall.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you live here, huh? Does it bother you to be in an all-female dorm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, well, a little, sure. But there are always men around. During fire drills, more guys come out than girls. Never the same ones either. They come and go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I bet they do.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie catches herself and laughs. Max shares a smile with in the doorway.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I had a good time tonight, but next time, let's have some real fun.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, fine, uh, next time I'll bring Jack Nicholson and a case of Schnapps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good night, Max.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Julie enters the dorm. Max watches her through the glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: TITLE CARD: white on black: "WEDNESDAY"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CLOSE UP of a schedule's column heading: "Wednesday"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Max reads the schedule on the door. His watch says 11am; finds Wednesday 11am: "Julio's Death Metal Jamboree." He peeks behind the door-- the station is empty.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He starts to slip inside when...

dialogues.speaker: BETH, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Max!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He whirls, closing the door guiltily. Beth comes down the hall, laden with books.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, hi...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It was great running into your friends, but... you know... I feel bad about what I said. Do you want to get together later?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, I'm sure I have something to do that I've forgotten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, it's bad enough we fell out of touch, but we can't even have lunch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We had breakfast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Every time we try to do anything, you have an excuse, or forget to show up, or you cancel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You cancel on me, too.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Things have been a little, you know, awkward.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
